thread.title: 5 things you missed at Louder Than Life Sun.
thread.title_full: 5 things you missed at Louder Than Life Sun.

title: 5 things you missed at Louder Than Life Sun.
text:
5 things you missed at Louder Than Life Sun. Jeffrey Lee Puckett, @JLeePuckett 6:13 a.m. EDT October 5, 2015 Buy Photo Enthusiasm runs wild in the audience waiting for the next act on the North Stage of the Louder Than Life Festival on Saturday. 10/3/15 (Photo: Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J) Buy Photo 14 CONNECT 2 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
The 2015 Louder Than Life music, bourbon and food festival wrapped up Sunday with plenty of each, including all of the cheese-drenched tater tots possible, and it left a lasting impression: People really seem to like vintage rock 'n' roll, even if the vintage is relatively recent. I mean, Collective Soul drew a big crowd, which has got to be news for anyone who has bought a record since 1996. 
In case you couldn't make it to Champions Park, here are the top five things you missed, in no particular order. 
1. On a day where nostalgia ruled, Lynyrd Skynyrd was the big winner. Maybe it was the decision to play nothing but one huge song after another. Maybe it was the animated performance. Either way, it was an immensely satisfying set. 
2. Edmonton County was represented in fine style by Black Stone Cherry and the Kentucky HeadHunters. The HeadHunters' Richard Young had a blast singing the blues in the early afternoon and then his son, John Fred, pushed Black Stone Cherry through a strong set with some truly unhinged drumming a couple of hours later. 
3. Nashville's All Them Witches was a welcome reminder that you can't ignore the small stages. The band delivered an impressive set of progressive garage rock, straddling decades while being firmly in the moment. 
4. Shinedown, a weirdly popular band from Jacksonville, FL, actually suggested that racism, and possibly world hunger, could be cured by covering Skynyrd's "Simple Man," a song which the actual Lynyrd Skynyrd had performed not 20 minutes earlier. Neither happened. 
5. The weather. After a very trying Saturday, which began with a rain delay and then constantly verged on cold and rainy, Sunday was absolutely gorgeous. All festivals should be so lucky. Buy Photo Atreyu lead singer Alex Varkatzas drops into the photo pit for an up close performance for the fans at Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo The Louder Than Life Festival welcomed tens of thousands under grey skies on Saturday for a day of metal music, wild exhibits and so-called man food. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo A modern twist on the torture device known as the brazen bull was on display at Louder Than Life courtesy of a group called Sparseland.com 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Buy Photo Amanda Sutherland sports a unicorn costume for the come-as-you-are setting at Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Fullscreen Buy Photo Amanda Sutherland and Steve McKeethen share a selfie along with a photo bomber at Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo A variety of booths to help raise social awareness were on hand to enlighten the crowds at Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo A variety of masks could be purchased for those feeling in the spirit of things at Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Fullscreen Buy Photo Johnny Neece of Hazard, KY checks out the masks with a young friend who remained anonymous during Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo Fullscreen Buy Photo Mike Renner of Columbus, OH arranges merchandise in his What The Rock? booth during Louder Than Life on Saturday. 10/3/15 Marty Pearl/Special to The C-J Buy Photo
